Similar sentiments followed, in Arrow,2 Sen,3 Anderson,4

choice, etc, revealed preference has been much critiqued.
All the same, itâ€™s hard to see how to move away from it, with-
out paternalism: if people know best for their own livesâ€”
shouldnâ€™t we trust their choices as the final proof of their
intentions? How else can we avoid imposing â€œbetter valuesâ€
from above?
One way to respond is to say that people do know best, and
have wise values, but that their revealed preferences arenâ€™t
the last word on those values. But to establish this, youâ€™d
want another source of information on peopleâ€™s valuesâ€”one
that retains much of the resolution, robustness, universal
applicability, and democratic simplicity of preference.
Iâ€™ll develop such an information source here, by taking two
â€˜steps backâ€™ from revealed preference, widening the infor-
mation collected. Then Iâ€™ll argue that my new source cor-
responds with one definition of â€œvaluesâ€ used in common
speech. Finally, Iâ€™ll show how this new source can be used
in social choice and welfare calculations.
Preferences
A rich literature covers how revealed preferencesâ€”which,
when summed up, are called engagement metricsâ€”lead us
astray. You can often get people to choose something with-
out serving their real interests: you can misinform them, or
leverage their misplaced hopes.
Or, you can make it so people need your thing for what
once was possible without it: they need your car to get to
work, your social media account to find a job, your dress to
socialize with their friends, etc.
More broadly, you can manufacture social circumstances
where people choose your thing to â€œkeep up with the Jone-
ses,â€ to signal allegiance with their tribe, or because theyâ€™ve
lost the ability to coordinate a real solution.5
In some cases, the person will know their choice doesnâ€™t ex-
press their true interestsâ€”that they are bucking to external
pressure, caught in the system, or setting aside their goals
to conform to a social rule.6 In other cases, options have
been limited or biased behind our backs.
Given these problems, why does revealed preference still
play a role in notions of benefit and measures of optimality?
It has huge advantages as an information source: in the
resolution and robustness of the data provided, its near-
universal applicability, and the democratic simplicity of its
collection:
â€¢ Preferences say fine-grained things how about each of
us wants to live, informed by our local situations and
priorities.
â€¢ Preferences get at what we choose in the final analysis,
our real, battle-tested priorities, not just what we say
we want.

Attentional Policies
Iâ€™ll try to address the problems with preference, holding on
to these benefits. To do so, I want to take two â€˜steps back.â€™
The first step is to widen the conception of choice to include
option set formation.
A revealed preference takes the options as given. As other
authors have pointed out,7 this doesnâ€™t fully reflect how
choice works.
Consider my choice, with colleagues, to say something witty.
At ğ‘¡1, I choose to say that in particular (over staying silent,
or saying my second-place quip). But, at some earlier point
ğ‘¡0, I decided to invest my attention in finding witty things
to say. Iâ€™ve tried witty phrases on in my mind, and tested
situations for witty reframings.
At ğ‘¡0, I made a much bigger choiceâ€“I adopted8 an atten-
tional policy of â€˜looking for witty quips and reframes.â€™ This
is how I assembled the option set for my choice at ğ‘¡1.
I think this earlier choice, at ğ‘¡0, reveals more about me than
the latter one. Indeed, these attentional policies (APs)
might account for much of whatâ€™s called my â€œpersonalityâ€:
When making friends, am I cautious or bold? When consid-
ering a purchase, is my focus on price, quality, or durabil-
ity? When speaking, do I try to be witty, precise, or down
to earth? These may not just be â€œcharacter traitsâ€ I was
born with, but policies I adopted, which work together for
my way of life.9
Collecting an agentâ€™s APs is part of my proposal to im-
prove the information basis of welfare, social choice, and
recommenders. How could that work? You could use an
interactive survey to collect the agentâ€™s common contexts
(socializing, at work, in diï¬€icult conversations), and have
them pick what they attend to most in each.10
If they claim to have AP ğ‘ in context ğ‘, you could verify that
with followup questions: First, you could ask them about
recent moments in ğ‘, and what options theyâ€™ve found using
ğ‘. Someone with a policy of vulnerability should be able
to cough up various opportunities for vulnerability, recently
considered; some taken, some not.

Supposing we collected an agentâ€™s APs. How would that
compare with revealed preference data, in terms of resolu-
tion, robustness, universality, and democratic simplicity?
Like preferences, APs are informed by our local situations
and priorities, and say fine-grained things about how we
want to live. Indeed, they have a higher resolution than
Iâ€™ve let on so far: an AP about â€˜honestyâ€™ or â€˜vulnerabilityâ€™
is always short for a more specific policy, like â€œattend to
what I feel about each thing we discuss, and let my feeling
show,â€ or â€œattend to false impressions a listener may get
from my statements, and head them off with a disclaimer.â€
That is: having honesty as a policy requires a substantive
interpretation of honesty, and these differ from person to
person.
APs are battle-tested. I wish I could craft my words to
simultaneously be kind, honest, tactful, humble, and inspir-
ing. I wish I could, at the same moment, be precise in
my speech, aware how each word lands, aware of my own
feelings; transparent, calm, and centered; passionate; physi-
cally graceful, like a dancer. But APs compete for my atten-
tion. So, my choice to look for witty things to say crowds
out many other options.
Like preferences, APs are applicable across all domains in
lifeâ€”the moral, the self-interested, etc, and apply to many
kinds of contexts.
But, they score worse on democratic simplicity than re-
vealed preference. And, for now, itâ€™s unclear how an agentâ€™s
APs would provide a substitute for revealed preference. Iâ€™ll
get to that.
Constitutive Judgement
My second â€˜step backâ€™ considers the kind of judgement an
agent makes, when they decide to adopt an AP. Look at
these three cases:
(1) I watch the road while driving. I donâ€™t want to crash.
(2) Iâ€™m careful with my speech at work. My boss fires
anyone who speaks imprecisely.
2
(3) Iâ€™ve decided to be more honest with friends. I recently
opened up to a friend about a struggle Iâ€™m having.
Since then, the relationship feels more intimate, and
stronger; itâ€™s easier for me to think about what to say;
my friend is unexpectedly helpful.
In all three examples, the agent notes some benefits of adopt-
ing an AP ğ‘ in a context ğ‘â€”benefits like staying alive, keep-
ing my job, and having helpful friends. And in each case,
this leads to a decision to adopt it.
But, in the first two examples, those benefits come together
to make the case that doing ğ‘ in ğ‘ is functional, necessary,
prudent, or expedient. The judgement is based on expected
costs and benefits, much as a rational choice theorist would
hope. Iâ€™ll call this an instrumental judgement.
In (3), the benefits become supporting evidence for a much
larger claim: that honesty with friends is constitutive of
good relationships11, or at least naturally goes together with
them. The benefits suggest that honesty is going to be part
of any relationship I want to build, or is part of the person I
want to beâ€”not just that itâ€™s functional in achieving certain
ends. Itâ€™s a part-whole claim, or a claim to synergy, not a
claim about cause and effect.
Iâ€™ll call this a constitutive judgement. To make one, we
ask ourselves questions like: are Xs impossible without Ys?
Are Xs without Ys in some way lesser? Are there kinds of
wholeness that emerge only when an X has a Y? Note: the
evidence that goes into these questions looks a lot like costs
and benefits (additional kinds of wholeness, etc)! So the
raw materials for this judgement are similar, but instead of
building an expected value, we build a more general conclu-
sion.
Why do we make constitutive judgements, instead of doing
a cost-benefit analysis for everything? Other authors have
marked out a role for constitutive judgements in moral rea-
soning,12 higher-order desires,13 self-understanding,14 and
identifying natural kinds,15 but thereâ€™s also a case to be
made from bounded rationality:16 constitutive judgements
are cognitively eï¬€icient. Instead of asking each time we have
an X, whether we should also have an Y, we ask up-front if
Xs and Ys belong together. If we think so, we put Ys in our
Xs without considering each case.
Anyways, both kinds of judgement can have errors, and
are subject to reconsideration. Instrumental judgements
are more delicate, because they depend on a more-or-less
complete accounting of costs, benefits, and eï¬€icacy. For
constitutive judgements, you donâ€™t need such a complete
accounting: if the benefits youâ€™ve already noticed line up
nicely, you can take them as evidence of a synergy or whole-
ness. Youâ€™ll reconsider your judgement only if you start to
think you got the overall pattern wrong.
This gives us a way to tell APs resulting from a constitu-
tive judgements (CAPs) from those adopted instrumentally
(IAPs). Say an agent uses AP ğ‘ in context ğ‘.

**Aligning concepts**

I'm linking Attentional Policies (CAPs and IAPs) with human motivation frameworks. CAPs and IAPs explore how reveal preferences and instrumental judgments differ, and I'm mapping these concepts to frameworks like Maslow's hierarchy and Self-Determination Theory.

The distinction between **Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs)** and **Instrumental Attentional Policies (IAPs)** in your provided text offers a nuanced way to understand human motivations beyond traditional revealed preferences. To align these concepts with established human motivation frameworks, let's first briefly summarize CAPs and IAPs, then explore how various motivation theories correspond to these categories.

### **Understanding CAPs vs. IAPs**

- **Instrumental Attentional Policies (IAPs):** These are attentional strategies adopted based on a cost-benefit analysis aimed at achieving specific outcomes. IAPs are functional and often temporary, focusing on efficiency and goal attainment. For example, adopting a policy to focus on price when shopping to save money.

- **Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs):** These policies arise from deeper, often intrinsic values or identity-based judgments. CAPs are integrated into one's sense of self and worldview, guiding behavior in a more holistic and enduring manner. For example, valuing honesty as a core personal trait, influencing interactions across various contexts.

### **Alignment with Human Motivation Frameworks**

Several established human motivation frameworks can be mapped onto CAPs and IAPs. Here's how some of the prominent theories align:

#### **1. Self-Determination Theory (SDT)**
Developed by Deci and Ryan, SDT emphasizes intrinsic and extrinsic motivations based on the fulfillment of basic psychological needs: autonomy, competence, and relatedness.

- **Intrinsic Motivation (SDT):** Aligns closely with **CAPs**. When individuals engage in activities out of inherent interest or personal value (e.g., pursuing a hobby for joy), it reflects constitutive policies rooted in their identity and values.

- **Extrinsic Motivation (SDT):** Corresponds to **IAPs**. Engaging in activities to obtain external rewards or avoid punishments involves instrumental policies aimed at specific outcomes.

#### **2. Maslowâ€™s Hierarchy of Needs**
Maslowâ€™s pyramid categorizes human needs from basic physiological necessities to self-actualization.

- **Basic and Safety Needs:** Can be seen as **IAPs**, where actions are driven by the necessity to survive or feel secure (e.g., working to earn money for shelter).

- **Belongingness, Esteem, and Self-Actualization:** These higher-level needs resonate with **CAPs**, as fulfilling these needs often involves pursuing activities aligned with personal growth, relationships, and intrinsic values.

#### **3. Intrinsic vs. Extrinsic Motivation**
A simpler dichotomy often discussed in motivational psychology.

- **Intrinsic Motivation:** Mirrors **CAPs** through actions driven by internal satisfaction and personal significance.

- **Extrinsic Motivation:** Reflects **IAPs** with behavior aimed at external rewards or specific objectives.

#### **4. Approach-Avoidance Motivation**
This framework describes motivations based on the desire to move toward (approach) or away from (avoidance) certain stimuli.

- **Approach Motivation:** Can be associated with **CAPs** when driven by positive values or goals intrinsic to the individualâ€™s identity.

- **Avoidance Motivation:** Often aligns with **IAPs** when actions are taken to prevent negative outcomes or escape undesired states.

#### **5. Goal-Setting Theory**
Focuses on the establishment of specific and challenging goals to enhance performance.

- **Specific, Challenging Goals:** Typically relate to **IAPs** as they involve strategic planning and effort to achieve defined outcomes.

- **Personal Meaning in Goals:** When goals are deeply connected to oneâ€™s values or identity, they align with **CAPs**.

#### **6. Values-Based Theories (e.g., Schwartzâ€™s Theory of Basic Human Values)**
These theories categorize values that guide behavior across different cultures and contexts.

- **Terminal and Instrumental Values:** Terminal values (end-goals like happiness, self-respect) align with **CAPs**, reflecting constitutive beliefs. Instrumental values (modes of behavior like honesty, ambition) can correspond to **IAPs** when used strategically to achieve broader goals.

### **Integrating CAPs and IAPs into Frameworks**

Understanding CAPs and IAPs enriches these frameworks by providing a lens to differentiate between motivations rooted in identity and intrinsic values versus those based on strategic, outcome-oriented decisions. Here's how integration might look:

- **SDT Integration:** Recognize that fulfilling autonomy, competence, and relatedness can foster CAPs, while controlled motivations might lead to IAPs.

- **Maslowâ€™s Hierarchy:** Consider higher-level needs as fostering CAPs, encouraging behaviors that reflect personal growth and self-actualization, whereas lower-level needs drive IAPs focused on survival and security.

- **Intrinsic vs. Extrinsic:** Use CAPs to explore deeper intrinsic motivations and IAPs to understand extrinsic drivers, offering a more comprehensive view of why individuals act.

### **Practical Implications**

- **Welfare Economics and Social Choice:** Incorporating CAPs alongside revealed preferences (which often capture IAPs) can lead to more holistic assessments of welfare that consider both strategic choices and deeper values.

- **Policy Design:** Understanding whether policies align with CAPs or IAPs can enhance their effectiveness. Policies that resonate with individuals' constitutive values (CAPs) may foster greater engagement and long-term adherence.

- **Personal Development:** Recognizing the balance between CAPs and IAPs can aid individuals in aligning their actions with their core values while strategically achieving their goals.

### **Conclusion**

Aligning CAPs and IAPs with existing human motivation frameworks provides a richer understanding of the complexities behind human behavior. **CAPs** correspond with motivations that are deeply embedded in oneâ€™s identity and intrinsic values, as seen in intrinsic motivations, self-actualization needs, and approach motivations. Conversely, **IAPs** align with goal-oriented, strategic behaviors driven by external rewards or the avoidance of negative outcomes, reflecting extrinsic motivations and instrumental values. Integrating this distinction into established theories offers valuable insights for fields like economics, psychology, and public policy, fostering approaches that respect both individual autonomy and strategic decision-making.
